lg.l: I'm singing a song to you[,] South,
Here in the northern shade—
A song that is sung by the mouth
Of the spirit that dwells in the glade.
It breathes of the lichen and moss,
Its rhythm is peacefully calm,
And glides through the sunbeams that glimmer across,
Under the Nikau palm. Nikau palm. The nikau, New Zealand’s only native palm, is found in the North Island and as far south as the Canterbury region in the South Island.
The fantails Fantails. Pīwakawaka, or the fantail, is a gregarious and acrobatic bird that feeds on insects. are twitt’ring above,
Full nimbly they’re dancing among
The branches; whilst, brimming with love,
The blackbird Blackbird. The blackbird was introduced to New Zealand in the 1860s and 1870s. is chanting his song.
The soul of the forest’s awake,
Emitting its heart-healing balm,
That floats in the shadow for melody’s sake,
Under the Nikau palm.
There’s rapture in manifold green
That reigns in the valley alone,
There’s love in its grandeur serene,
And love hath a way of its own
Of taking the flowers to its breast,
And giving a voice to the psalm
That floats through the forest at eventide,
Under the Nikau palm.
Then listen, dear South, to the song
That lovers unconsciously learn,
Who rest for a season among
The gullies of sensitive fern.
‘Tis fronded and restful and free,
Heart healing, consoling, and calm,
The sylvan song in the northern shade,
Under the Nikau palm.
